## Chronic Kidney Disease

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a prevalent issue in senior dogs. As dogs age, their kidneys often lose functionality, making them susceptible to this condition. While CKD cannot be cured, proper treatment can significantly improve a dog's quality of life and extend their lifespan. ## Arthritis

Arthritis, or degenerative joint disease, is another common ailment in older dogs. This condition arises when the cartilage protecting the joints breaks down, leading to increased friction, discomfort, and pain. Early detection and management are key to slowing the progression of arthritis. A multimodal approach, including pain medications such as Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs), dietary changes, and physical therapy, is often the most effective strategy. NSAIDs should always be used under veterinary guidance due to potential side effects like liver and kidney issues. Maintaining a healthy weight through diet and exercise is also critical, as obesity can exacerbate arthritis[6][7][9][10][11].

Behavioral changes in senior dogs can be indicative of underlying medical issues. Common age-related behavior changes can include increased anxiety, depression, or aggression. Regular exercise, mental stimulation, and consistent training can also help manage behavioral issues and keep older dogs healthy[3][4].

A structured feeding plan and regular exercise are essential for maintaining a healthy weight. Overweight dogs are more likely to suffer from additional complications, making weight management a critical aspect of their overall health. Even for older dogs, daily exercise and mental stimulation are important for preventing obesity and promoting general well-being[13][14][15][16][17].
